questions.stem: You’re at a metered on‑ramp signed “One vehicle per green per lane.” What should you do?
choices: Stop at the limit line and go only when your lane’s light turns green—one vehicle per green unless signs say otherwise.
Ignore the red if the freeway looks clear.
Go at the same time as the car next to you to save time.
Wait for a flashing yellow before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Ramp meters regulate entry. Obey the signal and posted instructions—often one vehicle per green per lane.

questions.stem: While entering a freeway, traffic is moving at 65 mph. What’s the best way to merge?
choices: Stop at the end of the ramp, then sprint into a gap.
Use the acceleration lane to match traffic speed, signal, check over your shoulder, and merge when a safe gap opens.
Drive slowly with hazards on so others go around you.
Quickly cross to the far left lane to avoid merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Use the full acceleration lane, reach near‑traffic speed, and merge into a safe gap without stopping.

questions.stem: Your exit is 1 mile ahead in heavy traffic. Which strategy is safest?
choices: Wait until the last second and cross the solid lines if necessary.
Signal for at least five seconds, change one lane at a time, and move into the exit lane early.
Stop on the freeway shoulder to wait for a bigger gap.
Back up on the freeway if you miss the exit.
questions.explanation: Signal early, change one lane at a time, and never cross solid lines or back up on a freeway.

questions.stem: Which statement about freeway lane use is true?
choices: Lane 1 (far left) is mainly for passing or left turns.
Right lanes are only for trucks.
You should weave between lanes to go faster.
Solid white lines mean you must change lanes now.
questions.explanation: Lane 1 is generally used for passing. Right lanes are for entering/exiting and slower traffic. Avoid weaving.

questions.stem: You’re alone in a standard gasoline car without a clean‑air decal. The HOV lane shows a double‑solid white barrier. What’s correct?
choices: Enter at any time to pass slow traffic.
Use it if you keep up with traffic speed.
Do not enter—HOV requires posted occupancy/qualifying vehicles, and you must not cross double‑solid white lines.
Cross the double lines briefly, then return to your lane.
questions.explanation: HOV lanes have eligibility rules and often double‑solid white lines that you must not cross. Enter/exit only where permitted.

questions.stem: When can you pass on the right?
choices: When there are at least two same‑direction lanes and it’s safe, or when the vehicle ahead is turning left.
Whenever you’re in a hurry.
On the shoulder if it’s paved.
At or within 100 feet of an intersection.
questions.explanation: Passing on the right is limited and must be done safely; never leave the paved roadway to pass.

questions.stem: At 65 mph on a clear day, what’s the minimum safe following distance?
choices: One second.
Three seconds, and more if conditions worsen.
Half a second if your brakes are good.
Ten seconds at all times.
questions.explanation: Use at least a three‑second gap in ideal conditions; increase it with speed, spray, or limited visibility.

questions.stem: A driver is tailgating you in the left lane. What’s the best response?
choices: Speed up to get away.
Tap your brakes to scare them.
Maintain your speed and, when safe, change to a right lane to let them pass.
Stop in your lane to make them back off.
questions.explanation: Keep your pace, avoid brake‑checking, and move right when safe so the tailgater can pass.

questions.stem: At night you’re being dazzled by oncoming headlights. What should you do?
choices: Look directly at the bright lights so your eyes adjust.
Turn on your high beams to ‘even it out.’
Look to the right edge of your lane and slow as needed so you can stop within the distance you can see.
Close your eyes briefly until the glare passes.
questions.explanation: Avoid looking into glare. Use the right edge as a guide and adjust speed to your visible stopping distance.

questions.stem: On a cloverleaf interchange, an entering lane and an exiting lane cross (a weaving area). What’s the safest approach?
choices: Accelerate hard to beat the exiting traffic.
Signal, scan, and take turns (‘zipper’) while adjusting speed to create space; change one lane at a time.
Stop on the ramp until the area clears.
Cross the gore area to skip the weave.
questions.explanation: Weaving requires cooperation. Signal early, adjust speed, and alternate when needed—never stop in a live ramp or cross the gore.

questions.stem: A large broken line and an ‘EXIT ONLY’ panel appear ahead. What does this mean?
choices: The lane continues straight with no change.
The lane ends or becomes an exit; move to a through lane early if you’re not exiting.
You must speed up to keep the lane.
You should stop at the end of the broken line.
questions.explanation: Large broken lines and ‘EXIT ONLY’ signs indicate a lane drop or exit‑only lane. Change lanes early if you need to continue.

questions.stem: A signalized intersection goes dark during a power outage. What should you do?
choices: Treat it as an all‑way stop and proceed when safe.
Proceed through at normal speed.
Follow whoever goes first without stopping.
Honk and continue if you don’t see cross‑traffic.
questions.explanation: A dark signal should be treated as an all‑way stop. Proceed only when it’s safe.

questions.stem: You see a curb lane marked ‘BUS ONLY.’ You need to turn right at the next corner. What is allowed?
choices: Drive in the bus lane for several blocks if you’re quick.
Cross the bus lane near the corner to make a right turn where permitted, yielding to buses and pedestrians.
Stop and load passengers in the bus lane.
Pass buses on the left in the bus lane.
questions.explanation: Do not drive or stop in bus‑only lanes. You may cross them to turn right where permitted and must yield appropriately.

questions.stem: When making a right turn across a bike lane, you should:
choices: Merge into the bike lane at least 200 feet before the turn when clear, then turn right.
Turn from the far left lane to avoid bikes.
Stop in the bike lane and wait for cyclists to go around you.
Never enter the bike lane under any circumstances.
questions.explanation: Enter the bike lane within about 200 feet of your turn when clear, yield to cyclists, and complete the right turn.

questions.stem: Before opening your driver‑side door next to parked cars and a bike lane, you should:
choices: Open quickly so cyclists have to slow.
Check mirrors and look over your shoulder for cyclists and traffic, then open only when safe.
Rely on your passengers to warn you.
Honk and open the door immediately.
questions.explanation: The door zone is hazardous. Always check mirrors and over your shoulder before opening doors into traffic.

questions.stem: A streetcar has stopped at a marked safety zone with pedestrians boarding. You may pass at:
choices: Any speed if you don’t hit cones.
No more than 10 mph, watching for people.
35 mph if you honk first.
Only if you pass on the left of the streetcar.
questions.explanation: At safety zones, pass at no more than about 10 mph and watch for pedestrians.

questions.stem: Which curb color means ‘no stopping, standing, or parking’ (except where specifically allowed)?
choices: Green
Red
Yellow
White
questions.explanation: Red curbs generally prohibit stopping, standing, or parking.

questions.stem: When parallel parking next to a curb, your wheels must be within:
choices: 3 feet of the curb.
18 inches of the curb.
6 inches of the curb.
Any distance if you used hazards.
questions.explanation: Park within approximately 18 inches of the curb.

questions.stem: A yellow curb generally means:
choices: Commercial/loading zone—stop only to load or unload as permitted; non‑commercial drivers usually must stay with the vehicle.
Unlimited passenger parking.
Disabled parking only.
No stopping at any time.
questions.explanation: Yellow curbs are typically for loading; time and conditions vary by sign—follow local rules.

questions.stem: How should you turn your wheels when you park facing uphill next to a curb?
choices: Toward the curb.
Away from the curb, and let the vehicle roll back slightly to set the wheel against the curb.
Straight ahead.
Any direction if the parking brake works.
questions.explanation: Facing uphill with a curb: turn wheels away from the curb and allow a slight roll so the tire rests against it.

questions.stem: Under California’s basic speed law, you should:
choices: Always drive at the posted limit even in heavy rain.
Drive at a speed that is safe for current conditions, even if it’s below the posted limit.
Match the speed of the fastest vehicles.
Use high beams to drive faster at night.
questions.explanation: The basic speed law requires a speed that is safe for conditions, which can be below the posted limit.

questions.stem: When it’s raining hard and you’re using your windshield wipers, what lights should you use?
choices: No lights—it’s daytime.
Parking lights only.
Low‑beam headlights.
High‑beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Use low beams in rain; never drive with only parking lights.

questions.stem: Your tires begin to hydroplane at freeway speed. What is the correct first response?
choices: Brake hard to slow quickly.
Steer sharply to the shoulder.
Ease off the accelerator and keep the wheels straight; avoid sudden inputs.
Turn on high beams to see the water.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning means the tires lost contact. Ease off the gas and avoid braking or sudden steering until traction returns.

questions.stem: Your car loses power in the middle lane of a busy freeway. What should you do first?
choices: Stop immediately and get out in traffic.
Coast with signals on, steer to the right shoulder if possible, then turn on hazards and stay belted inside while you call for help.
Back up to the last exit.
Walk across lanes to the median.
questions.explanation: Signal and coast to the right shoulder if possible, activate hazards, and stay belted in the vehicle while you call for help.
